facts.text: Appellant became owner by purchase in 1945 of premises situate in Vile Parle, Bombay.
Under predecessor-in-title, tenant Thirumal Rao Potdar occupied a room at monthly rent of Rs. 20 including water rate of Rs. 2, with amenity of water supply from municipal tap.
Tenancy continued on same terms after appellant's purchase.
Municipal water supply cut off early in May 1947 due to predecessor's default in payment of municipal taxes; tenants including Thirumal Rao used well water from neighbouring tenant thereafter.
Thirumal Rao died in or about 1950; his widow (first respondent) continued in occupation, paying original rent plus annas 10 permitted increase (Rs. 20-10-0), without municipal water supply.
Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Act LVII of 1947) came into force on February 13, 1948.
Tenancy recorded in first respondent's name some time in 1951.
In April 1954, first respondent informed Municipal authorities that water supply stopped since 1947.
Municipality replied on May 24, 1954, that water connection could be restored on payment of Rs. 11-4-0 fee if owner's consent produced.

First respondent's pleader wrote to appellant demanding refund of Rs. 72 (Rs. 2 per month for 3 years), restoration of water connection, alleging withholding due to non-payment of dues, threatening prosecution under s.24 of the Act.
Appellant refused or neglected to restore water connection.
First respondent filed complaint on June 14, 1954, for prosecution under s.24.
Appellant convicted by 7th Presidency Magistrate, Dadar, on March 24, 1955, in Case No. 215/S of 1955: sentenced to 1 day simple imprisonment and fine of Rs. 150 (or 1 month SI in default).
Revision to Bombay High Court (Criminal Revision Application No. 449 of 1955) summarily rejected on April 22, 1955.
Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court refused by Division Bench on May 16, 1955.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on October 10, 1955.

legal_issues.text: Whether an offence punishable under s.24 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 has been brought home to the appellant.
Whether the withholding of municipal water supply was without just or sufficient cause and attributable to the landlord under s.24(1) read with Explanation II.
Whether the tenant 'enjoyed' the essential supply of water within the meaning of s.24 at a time when the Act was in force, or whether mere past enjoyment before the Act or vested right suffices.

petitioner_arguments.text: Raised a number of contentions against the conviction and sentence, including that supply cut off by Municipality due to predecessor's default, not appellant's act; omission to pay Rs.11-4-0 not attributable under s.24 before Explanation II; tenant did not enjoy supply after Act came into force.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.24 Bombay Rents Act; Explanation II inserted 1953

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant continued to receive rent including water charges without providing supply; omission to restore on paying Rs.11-4-0 attributable to landlord under Explanation II; tenant enjoyed supply as part of tenancy rights.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.24(1) and Explanations I & II Bombay Rents Act

court_reasoning.text: Supply of tap water is essential supply per Explanation I; omission to restore after Municipality demanded Rs.11-4-0 fee attributable to landlord per Explanation II inserted by Bombay Act 61 of 1953.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant continued to withhold essential supply.

court_reasoning.text: Second ingredient requires tenant enjoyed the supply; enjoyment must be at time when Act in force, not remote past before 1948, to avoid ex post facto legislation violating Art.20(1) Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Supply cut off in 1947 before Act; no enjoyment after Act.

court_reasoning.text: 'Enjoyed' means actual physical enjoyment until cut off, not mere vested right; sub-s.(3) refers to 'has been in enjoyment' implying recent use; s.24 to be construed strictly as exceptional remedy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tenant had right pre-Act but no post-Act enjoyment.

court_reasoning.text: Before 1953 amendment, cutting off by Municipality might not have been attributable to landlord.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions are inroads on landlord's freedom, strictly construed.

holdings.text: Constituent elements of offence under s.24 not made out as tenant did not enjoy essential water supply at time Act in force.
'Enjoyed by the tenant' in s.24 requires actual enjoyment during Act's operation, not remote past or mere contractual right.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Act LVII of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines offence of cutting off/withholding essential supply without just cause; remedies and penalties; Explanations I & II deem water essential and include omissions leading to cut-off by authority.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act 61 of 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted Explanation II to s.24 attributing acts/omissions causing cut-off by local authority to landlord.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits ex post facto penal laws; construction avoiding retrospectivity.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds offence under s.24 not established due to lack of tenant's enjoyment of water supply during Act's operation; conviction and sentence set aside.

key_quotes.text: No landlord either himself or through any person acting or purporting to act on his behalf shall without just or sufficient cause cut off or withhold any essential supply or service enjoyed by the tenant
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.24(1) central to offence definition.

key_quotes.text: the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on temporal requirement for 'enjoyed'.

key_quotes.text: it would be straining the language of the section to say that enjoyed should mean had the right to enjoy.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Such remedies which are inroads upon the landlords freedom of action, have to be construed strictly in accordance with the words actually used by the Legislature
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle of strict construction for penal provisions.
